prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: The provisions of the C.C.Q. set forth a number of conditions that must be met in order for a non-competition covenant to be legally valid and thus enforceable. Art. 2089 reads as follows:

2089. The parties may stipulate in writing and in express terms that, even after the termination of the contract, the employee may neither compete with his employer nor participate in any capacity whatsoever in an enterprise which would then compete with him.
Such a stipulation shall be limited, however, as to time, place and type of employment, to whatever is necessary for the protection of the legitimate interests of the employer.
The burden of proof that the stipulation is valid is on the employer.

Restrictive covenants must be in writing, but do not necessarily have to be in the same document as a contract of employment. Such covenants must be drafted in terms clear enough for a reasonable person to easily understand their scope and substance.

It should be noted that, if the contract is related to work performed in the Province of Québec, the written documents must be drafted in French, unless the use of the English language is specifically requested by the employee. A clause indicating that request should be added to all employment-related agreements drafted in English in order to alleviate any problem that could arise later on.

As is the case in the Common Law jurisdictions, restrictive covenants must be limited in both their geographical and temporal aspects. The scope of the covenant must not unduly prevent the employee from earning a living for a period longer than what is necessary to protect the employer from immediate competition. The clause must also indicate the types of employment the employee will be restricted from undertaking. As to the time, place and type of employment limits that will be acceptable, each situation is fact specific.[1]

Even though art. 2089 C.C.Q. does not create a distinction between regular employees and those that have a higher fiduciary duty towards the employer, the courts will take into account a former employee's position within the company. A review of the case law clearly shows that more severe restrictive covenants will be tolerated by the courts where an employee held an important position within the organization.

Article 2089 C.C.Q. does not currently distinguish between non-competition and non-solicitation covenants. Even though the principle developed in Lyons v. Multari[2] is not currently enunciated in any decision rendered in the Province of Québec, a similar development should be expected.

When a restrictive covenant forms part of a contract prepared in connection with a business sale, the courts will accept more restrictive terms as valid, especially when the clause is directed towards ensuring that key employees do not impinge on the value of the enterprise sold.[3] It must also be noted that, in the context of the sale of a business, it was formerly argued that a restrictive covenant would not survive. However, since 1994, that argument can no longer succeed in light of the drafting of art. 2097 C.C.Q., which reads as follows:
2097. A contract of employment is not terminated by alienation of the enterprise or any change in its legal structure by way of amalgamation or otherwise.
The contract is binding on the successor of the employer.

TRM Copy Centers (Canada) Ltd. v. Copiscope Inc. (1998), 85 A.C.W.S. (3d) 170, REJB 1998-09660 (Que. C.A.); Bergeron v. Dubuc (2002), 112 A.C.W.S. (3d) 1054, J.E. 2002-352 (Que. C.A.); Emballages Alpha inc. v. Plastilec Inc. (2010), 83 C.P.R. (4th) 455, 2010 QCCS 2124.
Lyons v. Multari (2000), 50 O.R. (3d) 526, 136 O.A.C. 281 (C.A.), leave to appeal to the S.C.C. refused 150 O.A.C. 197n, 171 N.R. 195n.
Corovessis v. 6656285 Canada inc., 2011 CarswellQue 1151, 2011 QCCS 476.
